channel.title: NASA Image of the Day
channel.description: The latest NASA "Image of the Day" image.

item.title: Hubble Captures Galactic Glamour Shot
item.description: This stunning image by the NASA/ESA Hubble Space Telescope features the spiral galaxy NGC 5643 in the constellation of Lupus (the Wolf). NGC 5643 is about 60 million light-years away from Earth.

item.title: Satellite Captures Active Fires in the Western U.S.
item.description: Our Aqua satellite captured this composite visible and infrared image on Sep. 29, 2020, which shows that fires and smoke continue to dominate the landscape of the western U.S.

item.title: Retroreflectors: From Apollo to Mars
item.description: When Apollo 11 landed on the Moon, the crew brought devices with them called retroreflectors, which are essentially small arrays of mirrors.

item.title: Astronaut Serena M. Auñón-Chancellor Examines Her Eyes in Space
item.description: Astronaut Serena Auñón-Chancellor examines her eye with a Fundoscope aboard the International Space Station with remote support from doctors on the ground.

item.title: Soyuz MS-16 Spacecraft Docked to the Space Station
item.description: Pictured is the Soyuz MS-16 crew ship, currently docked to the International Space Station's Poisk module.

item.title: Hubble Shoots the Moon
item.description: This image from 1991 shows Earth's Moon, with its dark basaltic mare, clearly visible in great detail.

item.title: NASA Has Eyes on the Universe
item.description: Humanity has "eyes" that can detect all different types of light through telescopes around the globe and a fleet of observatories in space.

item.title: Cyclones of Color at Jupiter’s North Pole
item.description: Cyclones at the north pole of Jupiter appear as swirls of striking colors in this extreme false color rendering of an image from NASA’s Juno mission.

item.title: Ellen Ochoa Shakes Hands with First Humanoid Robot to Head to Station
item.description: Then-NASA Johnson Space Center deputy director Ellen Ochoa poses for a photo with Robonaut 2 (R2) during media day in the Space Vehicle Mock-up Facility on Aug. 4, 2010.

item.title: Moon Shadow Over Jupiter
item.description: Jupiter's volcanically active moon Io casts its shadow on the planet in this dramatic image from NASA's Juno spacecraft.

item.title: Franklin Chang-Diaz Performs a Spacewalk on the STS-111 Mission
item.description: In this mage from June 2002, astronaut Franklin R. Chang-Diaz works with a grapple fixture during a spacewalk to perform work on the International Space Station.

item.title: A New View of Jupiter's Storms
item.description: A unique and exciting detail of Hubble’s snapshot appears at mid-northern latitudes as a bright, white, stretched-out storm traveling around the planet at 350 miles per hour.

item.title: NASA Image Shows Fires, Hurricanes Across the U.S.
item.description: NASA's Aqua satellite captured this true-color image of the United States on Sep. 15, 2020, showing the fires in the West, the smoke from those fires drifting over the country, several hurricanes converging from different angles.

item.title: Frank Rubio: From Pilot to Doctor to Astronaut
item.description: Dr. Frank Rubio was selected by NASA to join the 2017 Astronaut Candidate Class. He reported for duty in August 2017 and having completed the initial astronaut candidate training is now eligible for a mission assignment.

item.title: She's Back: Kate Rubins Set to Return to Space Station
item.description: During her first mission to space and to the International Space Station, Kate Rubins became the first person to sequence DNA in space.

item.title: Hubble Stows a Pocketful of Stars
item.description: Globular cluster NGC 1805, a tight grouping of thousands of stars is, located near the edge of the Large Magellanic Cloud, a satellite galaxy of our own Milky Way. In the dense center of one of these clusters, stars are 100 to 1,000 times closer together than the nearest stars are to our Sun.

item.title: Be a NASA Flight Director
item.description: Not every flight director is a legend, but some are. Take Eugene Kranz, for example.

item.title: California's Creek Fire at Night
item.description: This NOAA/NASA Suomi NPP satellite image from Sept. 7, 2020, shows the night band image of the Creek Fire at night as well as the smoke from the fire causing lights at night to diffuse or "bloom."

item.title: Star Trek and NASA: 54 Years and Counting
item.description: Star Trek debuted 54 years ago on Sept. 8, 1966.

item.title: Completing the Roman Telescope's Primary Mirror
item.description: The Nancy Grace Roman Space Telescope’s primary mirror, which will collect and focus light from cosmic objects near and far, has been completed.

item.title: Booster Test for Future Space Launch System Flights
item.description: The first solid rocket booster test for Space Launch System (SLS) missions beyond Artemis III seen here during a two-minute hot fire test, Wednesday, September 2, 2020, at the T-97 Northrop Grumman test facility in Promontory, Utah.

item.title: Mars's Twin Peaks
item.description: NASA's Mars Pathfinder mission landed on the Red Planet on July 4, 1997. It's tiny rover, named Sojourner after abolitionist Sojourner Truth, spent 83 days of a planned seven-day mission exploring the Martian terrain.

item.title: Skylab Commander Jerry Carr Trains for His Mission
item.description: Carr passed away on Aug. 26, 2020. “NASA and the nation have lost a pioneer of long duration spaceflight," said NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine. Read the statement.

item.title: Sunrise Shadows Over the Philippine Sea
item.description: As the International Space Station orbited more than 200 miles above our home planet, the crew caught this glimpse of the sunrise casting long shadows over a cloudy Philippine Sea.

item.title: Hubble Views Edge of Stellar Blast
item.description: This Hubble Space Telescope image depicts a small section of the Cygnus supernova blast wave, the result of the "death" of a star 20 times more massive than our Sun 10,000 to 20,000 years ago. Light from this supernova takes around 2,400 years to reach Earth.

item.title: Spitzer Captures Stellar Family Portrait
item.description: In this large celestial mosaic taken by NASA's Spitzer Space Telescope and published in 2019, there's a lot to see, including multiple clusters of stars born from the same dense clumps of gas and dust.

item.title: A Fermi Spirograph and Women's Equality Day
item.description: What does this Fermi Gamma-ray Space Telescope Spirograph have in common with Women's Equality Day?

item.title: Artist’s View of a Planet Where Liquid Water Might Exist
item.description: A newly discovered, roughly Earth-sized planet orbiting our nearest neighboring star might be habitable, according to a team of astronomers using the European Southern Observatory's 3.6-meter telescope at La Silla, Chile.

item.title: Defining Radiation Risk to Astronauts
item.description: In this image, one of the radiation detectors for the Radi-N2 experiment floats in the space station. This device will help researchers explore the radition risk to humans in space.

item.title: Hubble Hooks a Supernova Host Galaxy
item.description: Galaxy NGC 2442, seen here by the Hubble Space Telescope, is nicknamed the Meathook galaxy owing to its extremely asymmetrical and irregular shape.

item.title: Station Crew Spots Hurricane Genevieve
item.description: Hurricane Genevieve is pictured off the Pacific coast of Mexico from the International Space Station.

item.title: NASA Is Developing an All-Electric X-57 X-Plane: A Cleaner Way to Fly
item.description: We're celebrating National Aviation Day! After all, we are the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. Aviation and aeronautics are as much a part of our mission as space travel.

item.title: Canadarm2 and Japan's HTV-9 Resupply Ship
item.description: The versatile Canadarm2 robotic arm is poised to grapple and remove the HTV-9 resupply craft from the space station's Harmony module.

item.title: Capturing an Avalanche on Mars
item.description: Hi-RISE, the High-Resolution Imaging Science Experiment camera aboard NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter (MRO) captured this avalanche plunging down a 1,640-foot-tall cliff.

item.title: Astronaut Chris Cassidy Does Housekeeping in Space
item.description: This past weekend, NASA astronaut and Expedition 63 Commander Chris Cassidy was no exception as he collected trash for disposal during weekend housekeeping activities.

item.title: NASA Begins Installing Orion Adapter for First Artemis Moon Flight
item.description: Through the Artemis program, NASA is working to land the first woman and the next man on the Moon by 2024.

item.title: Candy-Colored Phobos
item.description: As of March 2020, our Mars Odyssey has captured these six views of the Martian moon Phobos.

item.title: Artist Concept of Space Launch System on Launchpad
item.description: This concept depicts the SLS Block 1 crew configuration that will be used on the Artemis missions to the Moon.

item.title: This Gas Giant Is Pretty in Pink
item.description: If humans could travel to this giant planet, we would see a world still glowing from the heat of its formation with a color reminiscent of a dark cherry blossom, a dull magenta.

item.title: One Rehearsal Away from Touching Asteroid Bennu
item.description: NASA's OSIRIS-REx is ready for touchdown on asteroid Bennu.

item.title: Hubble Sees Near and Far
item.description: The barred spiral galaxy known as NGC 4907 shows its starry face from 270 million light-years away to anyone who can see it from the Northern Hemisphere. Appearing in this Hubble image to shine brightly below the galaxy is a star that is actually within our own Milky Way galaxy.

item.title: A Starry Sky Above the Earth's Atmospheric Glow
item.description: This long-exposure photograph captures a starry sky above the Earth's atmospheric glow.

item.title: Curiosity Celebrates 8 Years on the Red Planet
item.description: NASA's Curiosity Mars Rover touched down eight years ago, on Aug. 5, 2012, and will soon be joined by a second rover, Perseverance.

item.title: Outbursts from a Double Star System
item.description: For decades, astronomers have known about irregular outbursts from the double star system V745 Sco, which is located about 25,000 light years from Earth.

item.title: SpaceX Crew Dragon Endeavour Lifted Aboard Recovery Ship
item.description: Robert Behnken and Douglas Hurley are aboard the SpaceX Crew Dragon Endeavour spacecraft as it is lifted onto the SpaceX GO Navigator recovery ship shortly after landing.

item.title: Crew Dragon Safely Returns Astronauts
item.description: NASA astronauts Robert Behnken, left, and Douglas Hurley are seen inside the SpaceX Crew Dragon Endeavour spacecraft onboard the SpaceX GO Navigator recovery ship shortly after having landed in the Gulf of Mexico.

item.title: SpaceX Crew Dragon As It Approached the Space Station
item.description: Astronauts Doug Hurley and Bob Behnken of NASA's Commercial Crew Program are aboard the SpaceX Crew Dragon as it approaches the International Space Station.

item.title: A Different View of the Mars Perseverance Launch
item.description: The engines fired as a United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket with NASA’s Mars Perseverance rover onboard launched from Space Launch Complex 41, Thursday, July 30, 2020.

item.title: Liftoff to the Red Planet!
item.description: A United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket with NASA’s Mars 2020 Perseverance rover onboard launches from Space Launch Complex 41 at Cape Canaveral Air Force Station, Thursday, July 30, 2020.

item.title: Mars Perseverance: Prepared for Launch to the Red Planet
item.description: A United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket with NASA’s Mars 2020 Perseverance rover onboard is seen illuminated by spotlights on the launch pad at Space Launch Complex 41.

item.title: Countdown to Mars
item.description: A United Launch Alliance Atlas V rocket with NASA’s Mars 2020 Perseverance rover onboard is seen as it is rolled out of the Vertical Integration Facility to the launch pad at Space Launch Complex 41.

item.title: Jezero Crater, Landing Site for the Mars Perseverance Rover
item.description: This image of Jezero Crater, the landing site for the Mars Perseverance Rover, was taken by instruments on NASA's Mars Reconnaissance Orbiter.

item.title: Carrying a Telescope Aloft
item.description: Carried by a balloon the size of a football stadium, ASTHROS will use a telescope to observe wavelengths of light that aren't visible from the ground.

item.title: Apollo 11 Aboard the USS Hornet
item.description: This image, taken on July 24, 1969, shows the Apollo 11 command codule and the Mobile Quarantine Facility (MQF) are photographed aboard the USS Hornet

item.title: Comet NEOWISE Streaks Across the Sky Above Lone Pine Lake
item.description: Comet NEOWISE streaked across the sky above the tree line of Lone Pine Lake, located on the Mount Whitney Trail in the Eastern Sierra Nevada Mountains in California.

item.title: Developing Technologies to Send Humans to Mars
item.description: NASA is developing technologies to send humans to the Red Planet.

item.title: Apollo 11: Returning from the Moon
item.description: On July 21, 1969, command and service module pilot Michael Collins photographed this close-up view of the docking target on the Apollo 11 Lunar Module from the Command Module.

item.title: We Came in Peace for All Mankind
item.description: On July 20, 1969, two American astronauts made history by landing on the surface of another celestial body.

item.title: The Apollo-Soyuz Test Project: An Orbital Partnership Is Born
item.description: On July 17, 1975, something momentous happened: two Cold War rivals met in space. When their respective spacecraft rendezvoused and docked, a new era of cooperative ventures in space began.

item.title: Apollo 11 Launches into History
item.description: At 9:32 a.m. EDT on July 16, 1969, the Apollo 11 mission launched via a Saturn V rocket on a mission to the Moon.
